postsData.name:
G. Brent Barkin
G. Brent Barkin
postsData.content:
2015 post series, number 16...

This post will be about the majority of the emails and LinkedIn outreach that I get. For lack of a better term, I will use the term
to describe this group.

The company I run and those that I have worked with have used this tool in the past from a variety of companies. Haven't found one that works yet. All of these groups claim to have solved the cold outreach issue. using their software, technique, technology, they can increase the amount of "qualified leads" and turbocharge the efforts of your sales team.

I have no doubt that there are companies that do this, do this with advanced software, and have a formula that takes the sales funnel and drastically increases the number of targeted sales calls a company takes, ultimately increasing sales and revenue more cheaply than the age-old technique of a salesman using the yellow pages and a rolodex. Ok, I am old enough for thePages reference, not really the rolodex reference, but giving it a go anyway.

The issue is this is textbook white noise. There are so many companies that do this now--and many that just resell a service that someone else does, that it is next to impossible to review all of their products. My team could spend weeks simply vetting them all, and honestly, all of the products claim to do something incredibly similar. Because there are so many companies that claim to do this ultimately after trying and failing with one it is next to impossible and illogical to try another source.

Has anyone found one that works? Would love to hear it. I trust the referral more than the 5 emails and messages I have received today.

Oh, and next post will be about the podcast interview requests...

comments.commentText: The massive amount of outreach I receive is nuts these days. So on one hand its creating tons of noise and hurting sales people. On the other, its actually widening the gap between GREAT salesmen-ship and crap sales tactics. Silver lining in everything!

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Its indeed overwhelming with so many options. Im curious to see if anyone has had success with a tool that truly delivers results!

Abigail Clarke
Abigail Clarke
postsData.content:
What you think is your biggest setback could actually be your biggest breakthrough.

I know it doesn’t feel like it when you’re in the middle of it. When a client leaves, when an idea doesn’t work, when the challenge feels like too much. But trust me on this, it’ll push you in the direction you’re meant to go.

- That client who left? It’ll make space for the ones who actually value what you do.

- The idea that flopped? It’ll teach you more about what doesn’t work than any win ever could.

- The challenge you didn’t see coming? It’ll give you the resilience to handle anything.

Setbacks aren’t the end, they’re redirections. Most of the time, they lead to breakthroughs you didn’t even realise you needed.

So, if you’re going through it right now, just keep moving. You’ll look back and realise it all made sense in the end.

Stanford University Graduate School of Business
Stanford University Graduate School of Business
postsData.content:
You don’t have to be based in a thriving metropolis to build a thriving business. As entrepreneur Sumit Sinhal has discovered, sometimes the most promising opportunities lie in overlooked places.

The founder of Kins Health, a growing healthcare company in West Bengal, India, Sinhal chose to build his business in Siliguri, a small town nestled between Nepal, Bhutan, and Bangladesh. As Kins brings cutting-edge health care to underserved and hard-to-reach communities, Sinhal aims to harness the power of digital technology to reach patients wherever they are, from their workplaces to their homes.

Sinhal has discovered that success in remote markets requires building more than just a business. "Businesses do not exist in isolation," he notes. "When you're working in a resource-limited setting, you have to build everything over time" — from infrastructure to employee mindset, elements that might come ready-made in major cities.

Looking ahead, Sinhal sees technology as key to scaling impact. "I think our company and healthcare as an industry is at an inflection point," he says. His vision includes creating "docpreneurs" — helping doctors become digitally-savvy business owners who can expand healthcare access in other remote areas. "If it can work here, it can possibly work at a lot of other places as well."


Grit & Growth is a podcast from @Stanford Seed in which entrepreneurs from emerging markets share their stories, and faculty and business experts offer insights.
postsData.commentAdded: Inspiring journey, Sumit! Your vision for leveraging technology in remote healthcare is a game-changer. Excited to see the impact unfold! 🌟

postsData.name:
Ned Arick
Ned Arick
postsData.content:
You don’t need another tool.

You don’t need another framework.

You don’t need another so called “expert.”

(...also if they have “expert” in their name, they’re probably not one...)

What you do need?

To do the work.

Stop overanalyzing.

Stop testing every shiny new thing.

Just commit and execute.

We didn’t exit for 8 figures in 18 months by chasing trends.

We shut out the noise, surrounded ourselves with real operators, and put in the work.

Here’s the truth:

Most of what’s hyped as “NEW” is just old strategies with better marketing.

Ignore the noise. Double down on what works.

And be very careful who you listen to, because if it sounds high level, it’s probably coming from someone who’s never actually done it... and even worse they're trying to sell you their high level BS.

Be safe out there kids!

comments.commentText: Ned Arick be safe out there—that’s the best advice! lol I’m guilty of what you just shared here brotha! A few months ago, I spent hours overanalyzing signal-based outbound. As soon as I put it into practice, I realized that, as fascinating as it sounds, it won’t necessarily work magic like many “experts” claim it will—at least not for my stage. To your point, the best way is to put our heads down and do the hard work.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Focus on execution, not distractions. Real success comes from consistent effort and learning from those who’ve truly “been there.” 🚀

postsData.content:
I just saw this video of the first ever fully-automated McDonalds. 

If there was ever a reminder that automation and AI are coming....

This is it 

It’s a little scary, but it’s also the reality.

Here are 4 things I’m doing to not be left behind as things change:

1 / I joined a community of founders

Being around other entrepreneurs has been a game-changer for me.

I’ve learned from their experiences, borrowed their strategies, and gotten insights I wouldn’t have figured out alone.

Entrepreneurship doesn’t have to be a solo journey.

——

2/ I ask better questions

The right question leads to the right solution.

Every day, I’m asking:

- What’s the next trend I should be watching?
- How can I use AI to save time?
- Where am I falling behind?

Staying curious keeps me sharp.

——

3/ I learn something new daily

Whether it’s testing a new AI tool, improving my leadership, or reading up on industry shifts, I’m always in learning mode.

The world is moving fast. The only way to keep up is to keep evolving.

——

4/ I double down on what makes me human

AI can’t replicate emotional intelligence, creativity, or meaningful relationships.

That’s where I spend my time—building connections, solving problems in unique ways, and setting a clear vision.

Those are the skills that no machine can replace.



‍️ The question is: What are you doing to stay ahead?

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Embracing change and continuous learning are key. Excited to see how we can leverage AI while enhancing our unique human skills!

postsData.name:
Michael Walker Ed.D.
Michael Walker Ed.D.
postsData.content:
𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝗗𝗼 𝗬𝗼𝘂 𝗝𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝗮 𝗗𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻?

𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗸 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗹𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗺𝗮𝗱𝗲. Was it a good one? Or maybe one you regret.

Now ask yourself: 𝗔𝗿𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗯𝗮𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘁𝘀𝗲𝗹𝗳—𝗼𝗿 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲?

Annie Duke, a decision strategist with a Ph.D. in cognitive psychology, former professional poker player, and author of several books, explains in her book "𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝘁𝗼 𝗗𝗲𝗰𝗶𝗱𝗲" that we often 𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘀 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀—a𝗻𝗱 𝗯𝗮𝗱 𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘀 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗯𝗮𝗱 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀.

However, 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀𝗻’𝘁 𝗮𝘀 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁𝗳𝗼𝗿𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗱 𝗮𝘀 𝗶𝘁 𝘀𝗲𝗲𝗺𝘀.

Outcomes are shaped by two things: 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗾𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗼𝗳 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘂𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗿𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻𝘁𝘆 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗹𝗱 𝗮𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱 𝘂𝘀.

𝗘𝘃𝗲𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗽𝗼𝗼𝗿 𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘀—and 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲𝘀 𝗯𝗮𝗱 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗻 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝘂𝗿𝗽𝗿𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗹𝘆 𝘄𝗲𝗹𝗹.

Duke explains that 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗮 𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗳𝘂𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲 based on the information available at the time.

Because circumstances change and we rarely have all the necessary information, judging decisions solely by their outcomes is misleading.

Duke, as a good coach, leads with questions.

For example, when you 𝗿𝗲𝗳𝗹𝗲𝗰𝘁 𝗼𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻-𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴, ask:

If this decision goes poorly, will I assume it was a bad choice?
What information did I base my decision on—and what did I ignore?
Am I evaluating my decision process—or just the outcome?

𝗧𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘄𝗲𝗲𝗻 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗱𝗲𝘀𝘁—𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗺𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗮𝗻𝘁—𝗹𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻.

𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗱𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗸? 𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝗱𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗷𝘂𝗱𝗴𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀? Have you ever had a great process that led to a disappointing outcome—or a risky choice that worked out perfectly?

𝗟𝗲𝘁’𝘀 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗰𝘂𝘀𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀—I’𝗱 𝗹𝗼𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗵𝗲𝗮𝗿 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗿𝗶𝗲𝘀!

comments.commentText: Looking at it this way, I would say that the vast majority of people judge other people's decision entirely based on outcome, since they lack the context. Do they talk about understanding vs judging other people's decisions in the book?

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Its crucial to separate decisions from their outcomes. Reflecting on our processes can lead to better future choices. Looking forward to more discussions!

postsData.name:
Janusz Mirowski
Janusz Mirowski
postsData.content:
W życiu nie zawsze trzeba wszystko robić poważnie. Zdarza mi się za bardzo przejmować – pracą, statusem, rzeczami materialnymi. Ale czy to ma rzeczywiście aż takie znaczenie?

postsData.content:
NO HONOR AMONG CYBER THIEVES: 190 million Americans were exposed. This significantly surpasses earlier estimates of around 100 million, making it "the largest medical data breach in US history."

How did it happen? In short, the breach exploited a compromised account lacking multi-factor authentication and used compromised credentials on Citrix remote-access software to gain unauthorized access.

This resulted in a reported $872 million financial impact and 6TB of sensitive data exfiltration. And there is a lot of personal health info exposed. A lot.

Who's behind it? Black Cat ransomware group, who scammed the affiliate “Notchy” (who conducted this breach) pocketing the ransom payment without paying their share.

In response, the affiliate collaborated with RansomHub, attempting to extort Change Healthcare further, but no additional payments were made, leaving the stolen data in cybercriminals’ hands.

postsData.content:
Saying “no” felt almost impossible

when I was starting my career …

I wanted to please everyone,

to be seen as dependable and hardworking.


Every request,

every opportunity,

big or small

was met with a “yes.”


At first, it felt good.

I was helpful,

reliable,

and always available.


But as time went on,

the cracks began to show.

I was stretched too thin,

both mentally and physically.


Burnout became a constant shadow,

and the quality of my work

and my well-being suffered.


Then I realized something powerful:

saying “no” is not about shutting doors;

it’s about protecting your energy

for the right ones.


It’s about setting boundaries,

respecting your limits,

and staying true to your priorities.


Now, I’ve learned to say no without guilt.

Because every “no” to something

that doesn’t align is a “yes”

to something that truly matters.


If you’ve been struggling to say no,

know this:

it’s not a weakness; it’s a strength.

And sometimes,

it’s the most productive thing you can do.

How do you handle saying no

in your life or career?
postsData.commentAdded: Such an important message! Setting boundaries is vital for long-term success and well-being. Embracing “no” really is empowering! 💪✨

Peter Gostev

postsData.content:
DeepSeek's r1 model release caused quite a stir in the AI community, yielding a lot of good and bad takes.

First thing out of the way - it is not a PsyOp or fakery, it is a good model created by a talented team of researchers with a lot of small innovations, especially on efficiency side. The fact that it is released under an MIT license with a nice research paper is also a shift - it is by far the strongest (mostly) open source model for a while.

The most interesting thing for me about what they write in their paper is how well reinforcement learning (RL) is working. The coolest thing is all of the emerging behaviours (i.e. not explicitly selected for by researchers) that these models start to exhibit after all the RL training:

- Reflection: The model spontaneously rechecks and reevaluates steps mid‐solution.
- Self‐Correction: It spots mistakes and fixes them on the fly (e.g. incorrect factorisation).
- Aha Moments: It learned to pause, say “Wait,” and re‐start with a fresh chain.
- Longer outputs: It learned that longer outputs can yield better results
- Language Mixing: It can blend multiple languages or code snippets, since it only cares about getting the right final answer, not readability for humans.

All these behaviours happened without humans explicitly teaching these techniques. This only came from rewarding the correct answer.

The readability is a very interesting point. The original R1-Zero model was trained on pure RL and its 'thinking' was not comprehensible for researchers. If a model performs extremely well but 'thinks' in a completely incomprehensible way for humans, would we be ok with this kind of model? Perhaps forcing it to only 'think' in a single language (e.g. English) would limit how well it can 'think'. If it learned a concept in Chinese or Hebrew, would it be forced to avoid it for our convenience?

To get to DeepSeek R1, they trained the base v3 model on some initial examples of the 'correct' chain of thoughts, which taught the model to think in a single language (mostly) and format chains of thought correctly.

And the last very cool finding was that you can train smaller models on the reasoning chains (incl. 1.5b model) and increase their performance dramatically.

All and all, this is a very interesting model and more importantly paper. This tells us what likely OpenAI (and others) are already doing and how impressive RL can be.

postsData.content:
Code rewrites and restructures are super important and sometimes time taking, having done it at FamPay, I’ve learnt a lot about it, but let’s break down how Pinterestdid it for their ads platform.



We see ads everywhere, and one of Pinterest’s major revenue sources is its ad platform, which delivers >$3B in yearly revenue.


But it is both that straight forward, their original way had a lot of problems.

Pinterest's original ad-serving system, "Mohawk," implemented in 2014, became complex over time, leading to:

- Lack of modularization
- Unsafe multi-threading
- No guarantees of data integrity
- Close coupling of infrastructure and business logic

These issues resulted in frequent outages and significant engineering hours spent on maintenance, which is not really good for anyone.

To address these challenges, Pinterest's Ads Infrastructure team developed AdMixer, a Java-based platform that handles ad-serving tasks, designed to integrate smoothly with Pinterest’s other systems. It ensures that multiple ad-related tasks are executed safely and efficiently across Pinterest's vast ecosystem.

The design principles included:

- Easily extensible with flexible frameworks and APIs
- Modular, separating infrastructure and business logic
- Safe-by-design, ensuring safe concurrent programming and data integrity
- Developer-friendly, with tools that increase development speed

The Result:

Since its deployment, AdMixer has achieved:

• No significant outages for almost 3 quarters, even during the holiday season.
• Delivered 2+ billion ad impressions daily and generated $2.8B in revenue.
• NPS jumped from 46 to 90.
• Supported hundreds of millions of users globally across 30+ countries.
• It comprises more than 380,000 lines of code and over 200 experiments by more than 100 engineers.
postsData.commentAdded: Impressive transformation! 🚀 Its inspiring to see how strategic code rewrites can lead to such significant performance gains. Great work, Pinterest team!

The relationship between cold calling and baseball is interesting.

To be a hall of famer you hit .33.Impossibly low hits to pitch %.

To be a good pro, you hit .26.

The fallacy with cold conversations is that, somehow, you should be a .95 convertor.

The reality is you will to be a hall of Famer, be a 0.10 hitter.

To be a great pro, you will be a 0.05 hitter.

These odds deter competent sellers from even attempting this valuable work stream. Especially AEs, who may have a limited window of view to execute this important work.

My advice.

>Persist with doing a demanding job and appreciate the maths.

>Re-imagine the purpose of the conversations you have with strangers.

>Activate follow-ups and call those people back, with purpose, and you suddenly and systematically create opportunities which scale exponentially.

This is how you become a PipelineHero

Micromanaging is Killing Your Team’s Potential.

7 Shifts to Empower Your Team:

You know the feeling…
Shoulders tensing, heart pounding, overwhelm rising.

Micromanaging isn’t just stressful—
it’s sabotaging your team’s trust and success.

Here are 7 ways to shift from controlling to empowering:

1️⃣ Set clear expectations, then step back
↳ Clear goals create confident, autonomous teams
↳ Teams make faster decisions and take ownership

2️⃣ Schedule check-ins that count
↳ Random interruptions break focus and signal distrust
↳ Space for deep work and stronger accountability

3️⃣ Embrace different approaches
↳ Innovation dies when we force one way of working
↳ More creative solutions and engaged team members

4️⃣ Build decision-making confidence
↳ Growth requires space for safe experimentation
↳ Stronger problem-solving skills and initiative

5️⃣ Focus on outcomes, not process
↳ Micromanaging process kills motivation
↳ Improved productivity and morale

6️⃣ Create feedback loops
↳ One-way communication breeds misunderstanding and mistrust
↳ Open dialogue creates continuous improvement

7️⃣ Practice strategic absence
↳ Your presence can inhibit independent problem-solving
↳ Teams build resilience and collaborative strength


Great leaders create other leaders.


Which of these shifts feels most challenging for you?

𝐃𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐒𝐜𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐟𝐞𝐥𝐭 𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐨𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐚𝐭 𝐟𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭.

𝐓𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞’𝐬 𝐬𝐨 𝐦𝐮𝐜𝐡 𝐭𝐨 𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧: 𝐜𝐨𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠, 𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐡, 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐦𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠.

𝐁𝐮𝐭 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐚 𝐜𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫 𝐫𝐨𝐚𝐝𝐦𝐚𝐩, 𝐢𝐭 𝐛𝐞𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐬𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞𝐫.

𝐌𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐡𝐬 𝟏-𝟑: 𝐁𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐅𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧

𝐏𝐲𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐧 𝐟𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭.
Learn to write clean, functional code. Master libraries like NumPy for numerical computing, Pandas for data manipulation, and Matplotlib for visualizations.
Free resource:

𝐒𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐬 𝐧𝐞𝐱𝐭.
Grasp measures of central tendency, distributions, and hypothesis testing. Statistics is your lens for interpreting data.
Free resource:

𝐏𝐫𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐜𝐞 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐜𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠.
Real-world datasets are messy. Hone your ability to clean, wrangle, and prepare data for analysis.
Free resource:

𝐌𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐡𝐬 𝟒-𝟔: 𝐌𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝐌𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠

𝐒𝐮𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐢𝐬 𝐤𝐞𝐲.
Start with Linear Regression, Logistic Regression, and Decision Trees. These models solve most day-to-day problems.

𝐆𝐨 𝐝𝐞𝐞𝐩𝐞𝐫 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐮𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠.
Explore Clustering and Dimensionality Reduction to uncover hidden patterns.

𝐌𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐫𝐢𝐜𝐬.
Evaluate your models with accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.

𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐒𝐜𝐢𝐤𝐢𝐭-𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧.
This library makes building and training models straightforward. Use datasets like Titanic or Iris for practice.
Free resource:

𝐌𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐡𝐬 𝟕-𝟗: 𝐏𝐮𝐭 𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐒𝐤𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐬 𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐨 𝐀𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧

𝐑𝐞𝐚𝐥-𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐥𝐝 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐢𝐬 𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐚𝐥.
Build projects with datasets that challenge you. Predict housing prices, classify images, or analyze customer churn.

𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧 𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐲𝐭𝐞𝐥𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐠.
Create compelling narratives from numbers. Use visualizations to present insights effectively.

𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐥 𝐝𝐞𝐩𝐥𝐨𝐲𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭.
Take your models live. Learn deployment basics with tools like Flask, FastAPI, or Streamlit.
Free resource:

𝐘𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐎𝐮𝐭𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐞?

By the end of 9 months, you’ll have a portfolio of projects, a deep understanding of ML, and the ability to solve real-world problems.

2025 post #7

Title IX ultimately ensures fairness of treatment for educational institutions between men and women.

Those of us in the wild world of
have assumed that this will factor into the world of recruiting
, which is effectively pay for play dressed up as NIL.

The issue has been that by paying the revenue generating athletes disproportionately to the female athletes, you would be directly violating Title IX.

And as of yesterday it’s official- universities must ensure fairness of NIL compensation, regardless of source.

Now this is no easy task. Boosters are enamored with the rev gen sports, and those are nearly all male (but this is shifting with the rise of women’s pro sports). The result is that deals abound for top tier athletes in those sports.

If there is a solution it lies in companies like- because those deals are based on
NIL. Influencers in general weigh heavy female. Content creation is key and female athletes hold significant advantages that often make them better influencers.

Brands, do your homework. Universities will literally come begging for you to source your marketing through their female athletes. Guys likeat Florida already know this and are sourcing insane deals for those women.

Get on the bus or it will leave the station without you.

comments.commentText: Don’t see how this new regulation memo can apply to Collectives, but we will see what happens. Not to mention, this regulation memo could be amended very soon after a new Administration ushers in.
Brant Richerson very true.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Its crucial to prioritize equitable NIL compensation and recognize the potential of female athletes as influencers. Let’s drive change together!

Steve Swanston
Steve Swanston
postsData.content:
If I were the CEO of a startup hiring my first salesperson, I wouldn’t look for a “closer.”

The customers of my (hypothetical) best-in-class SaaS product don’t want to be sold or “closed.”

They need someone to help them solve a problem.

So, I would hire a great TEACHER.

Contrary to some stubborn stereotypes, the best salespeople aren’t slick talkers or smooth operators:

 They are educators.

 Problem-solvers.

 Guides.

They’re the ones who earn trust with customers by asking the right questions, actually LISTENING to the responses, and making people feel seen and understood.

Pitching is transactional.

Teaching is transformational.

If you want to close more, consider hiring better teachers.

 What’s the #1 trait you look for when hiring salespeople?

comments.commentText: Curiosity. Asking thoughtful questions, actively listening, and engaging in a way that makes customers feel heard and understood. The best candidates don't just sell— they learn, adapt, and work with the customer to create success.
Joel Trammell - if all of that happens closing becomes organic.
Joel Trammell 100% agree!!

Good call out, especially for a start-up. Your company is not a known brand and your offering is not fully understood. You are going to need a seller that has the ability identify real customer problems and show how your product can solve those problems. And, they must be skilled at customizing their messaging for different buyer types. This isn't a hustler reading a script; but rather, this is a real listener who seeks to understand and connect.
Carter Cathey - especially if you are creating a new category or product. To be a pioneer you have to educate the market.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Great salespeople focus on relationships and understanding needs. Teaching fosters trust and drives long-term success.

Mario Hernandez
Mario Hernandez
postsData.content:
Most people don’t realize this: Nonprofits are some of the largest investors in the stock market:


Universities, hospitals, and foundations all rely on investments to keep the lights on.

Harvard’s $50 billion endowment? Heavily invested.

The Gates Foundation? Same story.

Sometimes their investments directly conflict with their missions.

Imagine an environmental nonprofit unknowingly profiting from oil companies.

Or a social justice group tied up in private prisons.

It happens. A lot.

Nonprofits are no longer just donation-driven organizations.

They’re businesses.

Smart ones are building endowments, investing surplus cash, and looking for ways to fund their missions sustainably.

Many nonprofits invest passively, chasing returns without considering the real impact of their portfolios.

If you’re a nonprofit (or advising one), this is where the game changes.

The Numbers:

74% of U.S. nonprofit endowments invest in the stock market (Commonfund).

Only 13% of nonprofits say their investments fully align with their mission (USSIF).

That’s a gap. And it’s costing them more than just credibility.

What Smart Nonprofits Do Differently

They Align Investments With Their Mission

If you fight for climate action, invest in renewable energy, not fossil fuels.

Tools like ESG funds and SRI (Socially Responsible Investing) criteria make it easy to avoid conflicts.

They Leverage Impact Investing

Instead of just chasing returns, invest directly in companies or funds that drive measurable social outcomes.

Example: Back startups solving water scarcity if that’s your cause.

They Use Transparency as an Advantage

Tell your donors: “Here’s where your money is invested, and here’s the impact it’s making.”

Transparency builds trust. Trust builds loyalty.

They Treat Endowments Like Fuel, Not Treasure

ADon’t hoard. Put your money to work. A smart portfolio can fund today’s operations and tomorrow’s growth.

My Advice?

Nonprofits need to stop thinking like charities and start thinking like changemakers with capital.

Every dollar invested can serve two purposes:

Financial returns to keep the organization alive.

Mission-aligned impact that accelerates the cause.

Stop playing defense. Start investing smarter.

With purpose and impact,

comments.commentText: The disconnect between mission and investment strategy is a critical issue that deserves more attention. it's a powerful way for nonprofits to amplify their message and engage donors more deeply.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Nonprofits can truly amplify their impact by aligning investments with their mission. Its time for a strategic shift in approach!

postsData.name:
Anthony Vicino
Anthony Vicino
postsData.content:
Your life could change overnight simply by making different choices...

Here are 10 choices that'll change everything:

1. Claim Accountability for Everything

You can either be the victim...
Or you can be the hero.
But you can't be both.

Choose wisely.

2. Level Up Your Network

No prizes are given for being the smartest person in the room.

Every room reverts to the mean.

Which means you only ever get pulled up...or dragged down.

The easiest way to level up in life is to spend more time with people ahead of you on the journey.

3. Cultivate Daily Discipline

I hate writing, but love having written.
I hate working out, but love having worked out.
I hate eating healthy, but love having eaten healthy.

You don't have to love the process...Do it anyways.

4. Turn Your Weakness Into A Strength

I used to blame my ADHD for being the reason I was failing in life.

It was an easy scapegoat.

Things didn't start turning around until I went on a quest to master my biology and turn ADHD into a super-power.

5. Creat More. Consum Less.

It's very hard to get paid for collecting dots.

Surprisingly easy to get paid connecting them, though.

**Dots = Information

6. Treat Personal Development Like A Full-Time Job

Skills are the only investment that pay compounding interest regardless of economic conditions.

7. Build a Business

Hustle is the motor.
Opportunity is the vehicle.

Doesn't do any good to strap a gigantic motor onto a row-boat.
Alternatively, a paddle doesn't do ya much good on a yacht.

Pairing the right hustle with the right opportunity is essential.

Which is why it's very hard to get rich as a W2 employee.
Wrong vehicle.

8. Ask Better Questions

Here's one of the best questions I started asking myself:

So What?

Once you realize that other people's perception of you...

Or their hate...

Or their boos...

Can't actually stop you...

Then you become something terrifying to the trolls and well meaning loved ones who would hold you back...

Untouchable.

9. Do More. Think Less.

A lack of knowledge has almost never been the thing that's held me back in life...

It's been a lack of execution.

10. Learn Higher Value Skills

You're paid in proportion to the magnitude of the problems you solve.

It hurt my ego to admit I wasn't very valuable to the world.

But it was true.

I didn't have the ability to solve any meaningful problems.

My life didn't really change until my SKILLS changed.

comments.commentText: This change, since more isolation is occurring, is bringing critics out everywhere. Others choices never mattered and never will. Critics, paid and unpaid, must love negative lives!
If you want different results, make different choices.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Each choice is a powerful reminder of how proactive we can be in shaping our destinies. Let’s transform our lives, one decision at a time!
